title: Lecture 1
text:
Inclusion criteria

Defines the study population
Defines the exclusion criteria
Simple example: “Everyone who had a total hip arthroplasty in Sweden”

Includes: all ages, all hospitals, all reasons for the prothesis, all types of prosthesis

Complicated example: Ovarian cancer

title: Lecture 1
text:
Coverage and completeness

Institutional coverage: proportion of all eligible units/clinics that are connected to the registry

e.g., 90% of hospitals performing the procedure are connected
Should be known by the register holder

Case coverage: proportion of patients who should have been reported from connected units that are actually included

e.g., 85% of eligible patients registered
The aim is to use 100 % but this is not always possible

Data completeness: proportion of required data fields that are filled in for the registered patients

e.g., 95% of patients have smoking status recorded

e.g., 80% of patients have blood pressure data available

title: Lecture 1
text:
What is recorded?

Some registers are mandated by law and regulations
Quality registers often have a steering committee and register holder
Reseasrh initiated databases according to specific protocols

title: Lecture 1
text:
Data linking

Unique personal identifier

Not in every country!

study specific id number
HSA

title: Lecture 1
text:
Unique personal identifier
(Swedish: personnummer)

121212-1212 Tolvan Tolvansson


10 (or 12) digits
date of birth-4 digits
assigned at birth or immigration
used in all health care contacts
used for all administrative data
sometimes reused after death
sometimes changed (uncommon)
sometimes inclusion criteria for register
similair in the Nordic countries

Denmark: CPR number
Norway: Fødselsnummer
Finland: Henkilötunnus
Iceland: Kennitala

title: Lecture 1
text:
Combining data

Similar registries in different areas/regions/countries

Different individuals but similar data

Same definitions and variables?
Same inclusion criteria?
Don’t get fooled by similar names!

title: Health data
text:
Positron extensions
Positron is an integrated development environment (IDE) for R. It makes it easy to write and execute R code, manage projects, and visualize data. It is made by Posit (formerly RStudio) PBC and is free for individual use.
Positron is based on Code OS, an open source version of VS Code from Microsoft. As such, it supports a wide range of extensions and customization options.
We will use GitHub Pull Requests. Search for it in the Extensions pane in Positron and install it.
Instructions for Git in Positron

title: Worskshop 1
text:
GitHub

One (of several) cload services for Git (most popular) Link
Good way to share code with others
But do NOT upload sensitive data!

Personal healthcare data is always sensitive!

Gitea - open source alternative to GitHub (get the same functionallity locally or on a server)

title: Worskshop 1
text:
Clone and commit!

Install Positron: https://posit.co/download/
Install Git: https://git-scm.com/downloads
Create a GitHub account (if you do not already have one): https://github.com
Open Positron
In the upper right corner press the folder button and choose “New folder from Git …” with the URL: https://github.com/eribul/crap and place the folder somewhere you can find it, tick the box “Open in a new window” and press OK
In the cloned project, open the TODO file and follow the instructions there

You have now cloned an existing public repo from GitHub, made some changes which you have commited and viewed the history of that repo.

title: Worskshop 1
text:
New project
Let’s make a new project from scratch!

Press the folder button in the upper right corner of Positron and select “New folder from template” > R project and specify a folder name as well as a parent folder. Check the box “Create a git repository”. Choose which version of R you are using but don’t use “renv”. Open the new project.
Create a “data” subfolder (use the “Explorer” pane from the left side bar to navigate through your files). This is a good place to store your data later.
Create an “R” folder where you can later save your R scripts.
Open the already existing .gitignore file. This is a file where you specify which files to NOT include for version control. It is already populated to avoid adding some unnecessary files (and hence to avoid unintentionally sharing those files with the rest of the world).
You should never share any sensitive data (and most healthcare related data is considered sensitive) so lets add that we do not want to commit anything which is later found in “data” subfolder. Simply type “data/*” on a new line in the .gitignore and save the file.
Add some data to the data folder by exectuting write.csv(iris, "data/iris.csv") from the R console.
Check that the file name of the new file in the Explorer pane is in gray. This means that this file will not be included in later git commits (because it is found in a folder which is ignored by git).
Open the README.md file and make some changes to that file.
Commit your changes (as you did for the previous crap repo).
Press “Publish to GitHub” (you might need to log in) and select public repo. If everything works you should get a notification in the lower right corner of Positron that the repo has now been published and you can click a link to open it in your browser; do that!
Open the README.md file in the browser to have a look
Press “edit this file” (the pencil symbol to the upper right of the file).
Make some changes to the file in the online text editor and press “Commit changes …”. Write a message and click “Commit changes”.
Go back to Positron and look at the source control pane. Press “Sync changes”.
The changes you made online should now be visable locally as well.

To share your repo using GitHub (or Git alone or another provider such as GitLabs or Bitbucket) makes it easy to collaborate with others and also to work with your projects from different computers. This is often done for software development, including for R packges. To collaborate within projects including sensitive research data, however, is often more difficult. But for this course we will only use synthetic data and can therefore be less careful for now.

title: Worskshop 1

data.table
install.packages("data.table")

title: Worskshop 1

targets




install.packages("targets")

Make your data analysis reproducible
https://docs.ropensci.org/targets/
Read through (and replicate the examples) from this book: https://books.ropensci.org/targets/

title: Worskshop 1
text:
What’s next?

You will now have a couple of weeks to familiarize yourself with the tools we have introduced here.
Take the time to read and practice to improve your skills.
Clone the https://github.com/eribul/cs1 repo and work as much as possible according to the instructions found within it.
You are free to help each other and to use any resources you find useful!
Try to do some work every day (it will not be easy, but it is good practice!)
